MONDAY, APRIL 29, 1907.

div.head: ARAB ART IN EGYPT
div.p: The twenty-second annual report of the Comission for the Preservation of the Monu- ments of Arab Art in Egypt is, as usual, belated in its appearance, says the "Athenaeum", but shows no falling-off in the vigilance or comprehensive energy of the body of experts who have been entrusted since 1881 with the difficult and delicate task of protecting the Mohammedan monuments, alike from the attacks of time and from invaders. The minutes of the monthly meetings of the board, and the reports of the technical committee upon which devolves the duty of inspecting the monuments and reccomending repairs and restorations, present a long array of evidence of the Com- missions unflagging devotion to its work and of its maintenence of a high standard performance. It is as jealous as ever of the slightest encroachment, whether by builders or railway companies, upon the monuments-even the least interesting-committed to its care; and the presence at its deliberation of such lovers of art as Yacoub Artin Pasha and M.Casanova, and such officials as Sir William Garstin and M. de Mohl, is a gurantee both of the quality of the work done and of the necessary support of the Public Works Department and the Commissioners of the Debt, from whom timely financial help has often been forthcoming.

General State of the Cairo monuments now leaves little to be desired in point of preservation, so far as the preservation of such peculiar Parish of old buildings as possible, and the chief interest of the present report lies in its record of restoration. We are always anxious when we read of restoration but we are bound to say that the indefatigable Chief Architect of the Cairo Commission, Herz Bey, whose hand and brain are prominent and every page of the report do as much to allay our fears. In his earliest attempts he was perhaps inclined to be rash, and the results were sometimes crude; but he has learned much by long experience and patient study and will naturally eager, as a true architect to carry into perfect realization his ideas of what Saracenic art really was in its integrity, he is scrupulous and adhering strictly and faithfully to the minutest details of the original designs. We know it was satisfaction that the condition upon which doctor Stanley Lane Poole especially insisted in his report to Lord Cromer on the preservation of the monument 10 years ago - namely, that every scrap of new work added to an historical monument must be authenticated by an inscription given the date of such addition- has been carefully observed. This is not only essential in the interest of historical honesty, but as her they observes, is also in keeping with the custom of the Mamluk restorers themselves though their motive was rather self-glorification than scientific authentication of the data of architectural history. The chief work of restoration at present in hand is that of the famous mosque of Sultan Hassan, on which Herz Bey has published an elaborate monograph. The details of this comprehensive restoration seem to have excited some criticism, especially on the part of that very competent authority Artin Pasha; But we must wait for fuller reports before dealing with this question. So far as we have ourselves observed his work, Herz Bey There is no pains to get it the exact original materials, designs, and colors, before introducing any modern reproductions; but it is manifestly impossible to reproduce the softones of age in New work. The principal Restoration lately completed is that of the fine colonnaded Mosque of el-Maridani, a famous Mamluk emir of the fourteenth century, who was Saqi, or cupbearer to the Sultan-en-Nasir b. Qalaun, to whose reign many of the finest Saracenic monuments belong. Those who saw this great ruin in the 90s probably regarded it as a hopeless Wreck. The Columns and roofs were short up with endless scaffold poles; stucco work was crumbling on the ground, the inlaid mosaics were almost indistinguishable; and the whole was a mass of dirt and dust. Yet for those who understood there was enough of the original work left to make restoration of bare possibility, and such treatment of a large Mosque of the congregational colonnaded type was eminently Desirable in order to show this type in its Perfection. Heather to most of the Restorations at Cairo had been restricted to the smaller to most of the transept and other types. The work upon L maradani was begun in 1897, and the mosque was at last we open for public prayer and April, 1907. It was certainly a Triumph of architectural scale. Walls, columns, roofs, utterly decayed and tottering, had to be taken down; but all the columns and stones that could be used again were numbered and correspondence with the detailed plan of the mosque, and set up again and their own place. Traces of conical green tile work were found on some of the crenellations - reminding one of the mosque of el-Nasir in the Citadel- this fact was not lost sight of in the restoration. Without any attempt to restore the whole building to its original state of decoration, which would have been a costly process, and might have a vote criticism on the score of gaudiness, the plan was adopted of restoring completely samples of each class, e.g. the painted ceilings , the Gilded Corinthian capitals, are represented by only a few specimens in the original colors, so far as they can be reproduced. the main object was the preservation of the building and its entirety not the reproduction of all the decorative details and the distinction was wise. The mosaics in the Mihrab, or prayer-niche, however, have been fully reproduced. Some of the original carved panels of the pulpit where fortunately recovered from Europe, but no attempt was made to supply the place of the missing panels by modern carving. The Dome over the niche presented a difficulty, since it had disappeared for centuries; but a new dawn was finally constructed. The ablution tank was brought from the mosque of Sultan Hassana step which has provoked critical comment, but which was perhaps justifiable, since it did not belong to the original constructions of that mosque. Herz Bey devotes an interesting appendix in the present report to an account of the history of el-Maridani's foundation and its restoration, and Prince of all the inscriptions, both medieval and modern, illustrating his remarks by 7:30 graphs representing the Moss before and after restoration. We are very glad to notice that, following the recommendations already referred to in Lord Cromer's report, no restorations are be gone until complete plan and photographs have been made of each monument in its untouched state. The commission is to be warmly congratulated on its scrupulous care of the beautiful monuments placed under its charge.

div.head: Hashish Smuggling.
div.p: The Customs authorities have confiscated 340 Kilos of hashish imported in waste cotton bales by a well-known firm in. Alexandria.

div.head: Omdeh Suspected of Murder.,
div.p: : News comes from Tantah that the omdeh of Shoubra el Sakhwish has been suspended from office on suspicion of having murdered a native of that village.

div.head: Foolish Rumours.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has issued a notice tothe Press that there is no foundation for the rumour that the coastguards had Seized a Caravan in the desert containing '5,000 rifles,

div.head: The Holy Sepulchre.
div.p: His Holiness the Patriarch Photies, after a "conference and with the approval of H.H. the Ecumenical Patriarch Joakim have given orders for charity-boxes-to be placed in all the - Greek churches, The contents will be. devoted to the Holy Sepulchre at Jerusalem.

div.head: 'European Murdered.
div.p: The body of an European aupposed to be Ruisian was found yesterday near the Mahfouz canal at Minet el-Barsal, It wag transferred to hospital, where the post-morteny examination, showed, that the death was due to strangula- tion. The body has' not. been identified, and there is as yet no clue to thé murder,

div.head: The Egyptian Mall Steamship Co
div.p: We hear on good authority, says the " Afri- can World," that the first turbine steamer of the above company will be launehed on May 28 at Glasgow by the Countess of Dalkeith This magnificently-equipped ship which will cross from. Marseilles to Egypt in three slays, is to be named the Heliopolis.

div.head: Accident to S.S. Semiramis.
div.p: :will be held on May 8, at The Austrian Lloyd S.S. Semiramis which left Alexandria on Saturday at 5.30 p.m." had to be brought back to port owing to a screw of one of the blades of the propeller having loosened, She arrived back at Port at 2 a.m. yester- day and with the mischief repaired sailed at 29 a.m ;the delay thus only amounting to 19 hours,

div.head: Fire in Alexandria.
div.p: On Saturday night shortly after eight o'clock the fire brigade received a message that the Government Hospital was on fire, but happily this proved to be false, the fire turning - out to be in the house of the Coptic Bishop, whose loss was not great. The fire was got under by one hydrant and chemical extinguishers in about twenty minutes and only one room was burned.

div.head: State Railways Time-Tabie.
div.p: We have received the time-table of the Egyptian State Railways for the summer Months commencing from May, which shows a great improvement on former editions both in style, binding, and the quality of the maps. This publication is on sale at the principal book sellers both in Alexandria and Cairo, and at the booking offices of the most important stations, price 20 Mill per copy. We detail the changes of the service on the principal lines in another column. National Bank of Egypt.

div.head: The National Bank of Egypt
div.p: that the necessary number of shares required to pass a definite resolution not having been represented at the extraordinary general meet- ing held in Cairo on April 20, it is notified announces - that a further extraordinary: general meeting 5 p.m., at the oftices of the bank in Cairo, for the purpose of considering a proposal to increase the share capital of the bank and modifying Article 10 of thé statutes.

div.head: Tour Eiffel.
div.p: The enterprising management at this po- pular variety hall have again added some new numberato their programme, whilst re- taining some old favourites. The remain and continue to evoke roars of laugli ter and enthusiastic applause their amusing boxing skétch, It was noted too that a greater number were present on Sat- urday evening; and we think this standard would be maintairied if the proprietors con- with -tinne to make more frequent changes in the programme.

div.head: Mineral and Aerated Waters.
div.p: Owing to the great demand for mineral waters of recent years; there have sprung up throughout the country makers of mineral waters of very inferior and doubtful quality.

These concoctions are a menace to the health of the population, and we wish' to publish this warning to our readers and the public general- ly against drinking mineral or aerated waters other than those manufactured by firms of standing and of good repute. Mr N. Spathis, the well-known merchant and mineral water manufacturer, has a reputation of more than a quarter of a century's standing for the reliabil- ity, purity, and quality of his manufactures, during which time he has Leen the recipient of over sixty testimonials from officers of the Williams

div.head: LORD CROMER'S LIFE WORK. A NATION'S GRATITUDE.
div.p: Commenting upon the movement to bark . the gratitude of Great Britain for Lord Cromer's work, the "Spectator" says :— "We note with great satisfaction that a moyement is on foot to bestow some special mark of the national gratitude on Lord Cromer and that it is suggested that this should take the form of a money grant. We very much hope that the Government will propose such a grant_to the House of Commons, and that Lord Cromer will not veto the scheme. It is no secret that Lord Cromer is anything but a rich man, and, though he never encouraged undue lavishness or extravagance in the style of living adopted 'at the British Agency, his official salary only just enabled him to keep.up the large establishment required by his official position, and to meet the great calls made upon the purse.of one who was not only the actual ruler'of Egypt, but also the head of the British coleny in Cairo, Lord Cromer's friends haye felt.for many years that his salary ought at least to have been as large as that of the Governor of Madras (£8,000) or the. -Ambas- sador in Paris (£10,000). . Yet, as a matter of fact, it was only £6,500, and this though Cairo is an exceedingly expensive place in which to live according to the European stan- dard. Lord Cromer's feelings in the 'matter made it impossible to suggest an increase of pay for the British Agent during-his tenure of the office, but we think if is only right that the whole matter should, on a new eppaint- sment, be.care fully reconsidered."

div.p: We would remind our readers that the address to be presented by British subjects resident in Ale andria and the neighbourhood may- be signed to-day and to-morrow at the Union Club or on Wednesday at the Khedi-vial Club.

div.head: THEATRE ZIZINIA.
div.p: On Saturday: evening Monsieur Stephanos Christaki, the teacher of eloention and drama- tic recitation, took part in a gala performance organised by his namerous pupils, on the occa- sion of his impending departure. For the first and most important part of the programme, Jean Richepin's "Je Flibustier" was chosen and proved a very acceptable item. 'The fine verses of the well known French playright were very intelligently given ont by Mr. Christaki in the title role of Francois Legoés, and although oceasionally his intonation was slighty irregu- lar,- his words were always clear. His performance right through was very creditable and his @fforts fully deserved the applause which aredted him at the end of the second'act. The other characters were satisfactorily handled by M.M. Hornbostel, Mors, Nicolas and Kremer land Mmes. Nicolas and Beraldi ; all proved themselves conscientious pupils and if, at times, their delivery was a little amateurish, their elocution was always correct and distinct. The evening closed with "15 Heures de Fiacre!" a two act comedy by Clairville and Nuitter aid in this, Mr Christaki brought peals of langhter from his andience. Although the piece in itself does not call for any special remark, the artists of the evening to whom were added M.M. Paal, Levy, Piron, Autofage and Blanc, did their-very best and succeeded Army of Occupation, medical men, managers.

In genuinely amusing the house,partly compos- of hotels, Nile steamers, etc., all testifying to the standard excellence of his mineral waters, All desirous of being absolutely certain of their sutomer beverages should make it a rule to see that they bear the name of Spathis." [Advr.]

div.head: GREEK SCHOOL AT CHATBY. FOUNDED BY MR. G. ZERVUDACHI.
div.p: Yesterday afternoon at five o'clock the foundation stone of the preparatory school for Greek children, to be built by the generosity of Mr. George Zervudachi, was laid in the presence of a large gathering of the members of the Alexandrian Greek community. Nearly five thousand persons were present at the ceremony which was most brilliant and impos- ing ; among them we noticed Hafiz Bey, Sub- Governor of Alexandria, Mr Gould, H.B.M's, Consul, Mr. Scotidis, Hellenta, Consol Gamanal, Dr, Schiess Pasha, Mr. Chataway, Mr and Mrs. Emmanuel, Benachi, Mr. Michel Sinadino, Mr. D. Tambacopoulg, Mr. and Mrs. George Zervudachi and family, Mr. Sivitanidis, Mr. Karam, Mr. Paleologo Giorgiou, headmaster of the Alexandria Greek boys schools with the teaching staff and the higher class pupils, Mrs Stampa, head mistress of the girls schools with teaching staff and pupils. The religious ceremony was conducted by his Beatitude, Mgr. Photios, Patriarch of the Greek Orthodox Church, who was accom- panied by the Bishop of Tripoli, Mgr. Teofanis Mosconas, and the clergy of the Greek Churches. After the ceremony was concluded and the blessing had been delivered, the official document was signed by the authorities and the leading members of the colony, and the stone was laid by Mr. George Zervudachi assisted by Master Constantine and Miss Kitty Zervudachi and the elder pupils of the gymna- sium.

Several speeches were delivered, the first speaker being Mr. Benachi, president of the community, who thanked Mr. Zervadachi in their name. Mr. Zervudachi in reply expressed his desire to do his utmost to further the education of his compatriots and instill in them the principles of humanity. Speeches were also given by Mr. Scotidis and Mgr. Photios and at half past five the assembly broke up. During the ceremony the music was supplied by the boys school band and the Greek philharmonic band.

div.head: NOTES FROM Cyprus.
THE LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL: (FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT).
div.p: Larnaca, April 19. The election petition proceedings are approaching the end and it is expected that judgment will be given case within the next few days. Meanwhile the Legislative Council has been getting through its pro- gramme and during the past week has been concerned witha private Bill relating to the election of an Archbishop, which is, here,an ever-burning question. The Bill, we under- tand, has now reached the Committee stage ; how much further it will go remains to be seen. Artesian Wells. The Artesian well-boring operations, which were commenced near the chief secretariat buildings some two years or more ago have now ceased, and the plant has lately been removed to another spot. The boring which had been carried to a depth of about 800 feet had to be abandoned owing to the rocky nature of the soil which was met with, render- ing further operations impracticable. It is to be hoped that better results will be attained from the new borings now to be commenced, as success in obtaining water by this means should prove a turning point in the general agriculture of the country. For the S.P.C.A. On the 29th instant a fancy dress ball was given in the theatre, Nicosia, in aid of the branch of the S.P.C.A. Owing to the date ing during the Greek Lent very few of the Greek conmmunity were present, which, from the Society's point of view, must have been regrettable and must have caused a diminution in the anticipated receipts. The evening, however, passed off very well and the dresses were gay and for the most part picturesque and effective. The gentlemen's prize went to a "Golliwog," while the ladies prize was politely awarded to the honorary secretary of the soci- ety. Other dresses worthy of notice were: Be- rengaria, two ladies of the Court of Louis XIV., Queen Elizabeth, a Norwegian peasant, and an early Victorian young lady ; while among the gentlemen's were Richard, Coeur de Lion, a North American Indian, Sir Walter Raleigh, Black and White, and the Education Bill. The theatre had been tastefully decorated for the occasion, and an excellent effect was produced by shading the strong central Lux light with coloured gauze, lengths of which were made to radiate from it and carried to the various boxes of the first tier. The Zaptieh band pro- vided the music. Amateur Dramatic Society. An Amateur Dramatic Society has just been formed among the English com- munity, with its headquarters in Nicosia. Its first private performance was held on the 9th instant at the house of Lt Col. and Mrs. Gore, kindly lent by them for the occasion. The programme was varied and consisted of singing, tableaux, incidental music and two diologues; The net proceeds go to a charity fund, specially formed by the society, Admission was by invitation only, but we hear that the entertainment was mich appreciated by those who were present. The society should be a welcome addition to the English social life at the metropolis, and prove the means of developing and displaying a fair amount of local talent. Cricket Match. On Saturday the 12th instant a cricket match was played at Nicosia, Nicosia C.Club v. The Island. Although the latter included some very fair players and were regarded as a strong eleven they suffered a disastrous defeat, for the home team declared their innings at 293 for eight wickets and succeeded in despatching their opponents for the Gi gl of 27. The latter then followed on, with scarcely better results and were all out in their second- innings for 57. A return match will doubtless be arranged when we hope to witness a change of fortune. Feeding of Animals. This spring has been one of plenty in the matter of green fodder, and cattle of all kinds have been able to get more than their usual allowance of succulent food. Owing to many rainy days, the green barley has not matured as rapidly as is generally the case and the animals have therefore enjoyed a longer spell in the fields than falls to their lot in average years. There has been a great shortage of Horses for the public conveyances and a considerable advance upon the ordinary fee has had to be paid. Tourists. The Limassol Steamship Company has brought, within the last week or two, several to the Island, either for business or pleasure. Had the weather been more favourable over here a few weeks ago a still larger influx of tourists from Egypt would probably have taken place.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley, Ramleh.
Ten minutes from Alexandria. First-Class in every respect. Very moderate charges. Bulkeley is the fashionable English quarter. Visitors from Cairo alight at Sidi Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha will leave Cairo for Alexandria by special train at 9.45 a.m. on Wednesday and will arrive at Hadra station . at 1.20 pm.
Colonel Richardson Drummond-Hay, Coldstream feast has gone on leave until April 27.

Lady Gatacre has presented to the Royal United Service Institution, Whitehall, several interesting relics of the later stages of the Soudan Campaign, in which her husband, the late Sir William Gatacre, K.C.B., was in command of the British division during the advance on Khartoum and Omdarman. They include the black flag belonging to the Khalfa, and also the head dress worn by the Dervish leader at the time of his final overthrow.

The marriage took place on the 30th April, at Martin-in-the-Fields, London, of Mr. George Francis Wilson, third son of the late James Wilson Pasha and of Mrs Wilson, of Ealing, and Miss Renee de Montigny Mai Lamprey, youngest daughter of Mr. J. H. Lamptey, of Brockley, Kent. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Hamilton Rose, M.A.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive will leave Cairo on the 6th prox. travelling- by dahabieh to Mansourah, where he will spend the night. On the follo- wing day his Highness will visit Matarieh and on the 8th inst embark at Port Said on board the Mahroussa for Alexandria, where his Highness will arrive on the morning of the 9th prox.

div.head: THE LATE COLONEL RHODES. MEMORIAL TABLET.
div.p: A few friends of the late Colonel Frank Rho- des, C.B,D.S.0., of the 1st. Royal Dragoons, have recently placed on thenorth wall ofDalham Church, near Newmarket, a memorial tablet to this gallant officer, whose distinguished career was cut short by death at the Appa in September, 1907. The tablet records the many campaigns in the Sudan and Africa, in which the deceased took part, including the actions of El Teb, Tamai, Abu-klea, Tamai, the Atbara, and Omdurman, where he was severely wounded. It also mentions that he acted as Chief of Staff to General Sir Gerald Portal on his his mission to Uganda, and took part in the siege of Ladysmith, and the relief of Mafeking. The character of the late officer is well-express- ed in the following eulogy with which the tablet concludes: A gentleman who knew not fear, a soldier, sportsman, prince of friends, a man men could but love lies here.

div.head: LECTURE AT PORT SAID. (FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT).
div.p: A most interesting lecture illustrated by lantern slides is to be given at Port-Said en Wednesday at the Eldorado theatre by Capt Armitage on "The Antartic Regions." Capt. Armitage (Lieut. R. N; R.) was one of the commanders of the Discovery in the expedi- tion to the South Pole and also on the Windward in her voyage towards the North Pole. The proceeds are in aid of the lady Strang- ford Hospital, and it is to be hoped for-the benefit of the hospital, which has proved itself invaluable to the port, that the lecture will be well patronized. The upkeep of -such an institution is naturally very costly and the income is not by any means too large The chair will be taken by — Langiord Clarke.

div.head: EGYPTIAN STATE RAILWAYS. ——
div.p: SUMMER TRAIN SERVICE.

The following are the changes on the prin- cipal lines made in the new train service which comes into force Wednesday:- CAIRO —ALEXANDRIA The 6.5 a.m.-train from Tanteh to Alexandria will leave Tantah at 5.45 am (to con- nect at Teb-el-Barond with the 6.50 train for Manachi Line) arriving Alexandria at 9 10 am The noon express train will arrive Cairo 5 minutes later ie. at 3.10 pm instead of 3.5 p.m. The 4 p.m. express train from Cairo will arrive Alexandria 5 minutes earlier The 4.50 p.m. express train from Cairo and the 4 25 p.m. express from Alexandria have been suppressed. A new express train has been organised between between Cairo-Tantah and will leave Cairo at 7.10 a.m. arriving Tantah at 3.35 am, (to relieve the 7.30 am. train) and retnrn from Tantah at 5.35 p.m. (ahead of the after-. noon express) arriving Cairo at 7 pm. The 3.40 p.m express train from Alexandria to Cairo will leave Alexandria at 8:45 p.m. arriving Cairo at 7.15 p m. The 3 pm. train from Cairo will arrive Alexandria half an hour earlier.
CAIRO-PORT SAID The timing of the 8 am mixed trin from Ismalia to Port Said has been altered and it will arrive Port Said at 29 35 am. instead of 10.55 am

ISMAILIA—SUEZ DOCKS. The 9.40 p.m train from Ismalia will start 5 minutes later arriving Suez Docks at 29.50 p.m. The 5.30 pm train from Suez Docks will leave at 5.40 pm arriving Ismalia at 7.48 Instead of 7.30 pm

CAIRO - MANSOURAH (Via. Belbeis). The 6.15 a.m. mixed train from Calioub to Zagazig will leave Calioub at 5 am. arriving Zagazig at 8.23 a.m. The 29.30 a.m. train from Cairo to Man- sourah will arrive Mansourah station 4 minutes earlier at 3.46 instead of 3.50 p.m. The 4.15 p.m. train from Mansourah to Cairo will arrive Cairo at 8.35 instead of 8.20 p.m.

CAIRO—LUXOR. A new express train has been organized between Cairo and Assiout and will leave Cairo at 9.30 p.m. arriving Assiout at 5 am, it will return from the latter at 10.40 p.m. arriving Cairo at 6.20 am to relieve the night expresses. The 6.20 a.m. train from Addiout to Luxor will leave Assiout at 5.30 am, arriving Luxor at l pm., to convey the passengers arriving by the new express train. The 3.30 p.m. train from Luxor to Assiout will leave at 3 p.m. arriving Assiout at 10.25 instead of 10.50 p.m to connect with the new express train which has been organized be- tween Assiout and Cairo. The 6 am. train from Wasat to Sohag will leave Wasta 40 minutes later at 6.40 a.m. to convey the Passengers arriving from the Fayoum Line. The evening express train between Cairo and Luxor which is due to leave Cairo at 8 p.m. will arrive Luxor 10 mts earlier, viz at 9.50 instead of 10 a.m. The 5.15 a.m. train from Minieh to Cairo will leave Minieh at 5 a.m. arriving Cairo at 12.40 instead of 12.50 p.m. The 7.20 am train from Assiout to Cairo will start from Assiout at 7 am. arriving Cairo at 5 50 pm (as now) The 6 25 am. train from Sohag to Cairo will leave Sohag at 6 40 am arriving Cairo at 10 pm (as now) The 9 15 am train from Sohag to Wasta will arrive at Wasta at 8 38, instead of 8 40 pm The night express train which is due to leave Luxor at 5 30 pm and arriving Cairo at 7.35 am. his been modified to arrive Cairo at 7 20 am. The 6.10am train from Wasta to Cairo will leave Fayoum at 530 a.m. to connect at Wasta with the 6.40 am. train to the South, and will arrive Cairo at 9 am instead of 9.40 am

ASSOUAN LINE. The 5 a m. train from Edfou to Assouan will arrive at Assouan at 10:32 instead of 10 29a.m. The 6.20 am train Luxor to Assouan will leave Luxor at 5 30 am, arriving Assouan at 2 10 instead of 3 30 pm The 10,30 am train from Luxor to Shellal will arrive at Shellal at 5 45 instead of 5 40 pm The 315 pm mixed train from Luxor to Edfou will leave Luxor at 3 20 pm, arriving Edfou at 7 35 instead of 7 25 pm The 5.45 am. train from Edfou to Luxor Will leave Edfou at 5:30 arriving Luxor at 10.5 instead of 9 45 am The 5.50 am train from Assouan to Luxor will leave Assouan at 5 am arriving Luxor at 1.40 instead of 2.30 pm The 3.35 pm train from Assouan to Edfou will leave Assouan at 3.25 pm arriving Edfou at 8.10 instead of 8.15 am

div.head:
TURKISH CUSTOMS PROTOCOL.
SIR N. O'CONOR'S HINT.

div.p: Simultaneously with the signature of the Customs Protocol, Sir N. O'Conor sent a note to the Porte hinting at the possibility of Great Britain, in concert with the other Powers, taking up the question of establishing effective control of the customs at any time that Turkey does tot observe her engagément. (Reutér)

Mr. Birrell, speaking at Halifax, said that the Bill dealing with the reform of the House of Lords would be introduced soon and that it would be more generally supported than was supposed. The "Daily Telegraph" believes that the Government's plan for dealing with the Lords is to provide a conference of the two Chambers, in the event of disagreement. (Reuter)

div.head: THE COLONIAL PREMIERS. SPEECH BY BOTHA.

div.p: The Premiers were entertained at a banquet at the National Liberal Club at which Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman was present. General Botha was the lion of the evening. In a strik- ing speech he said : "I did my duty aé a soldier during the war and am ready to do the same for the Empire to-day," (Reuter )

div.head: THE RUSSIAN PEASANTRY. DEPUTATION TO TSAR.

div.p: Peasant deputies have been received by the Tsar. They presented an address dwelling on the poverty of the peasants and the dep'orable economic position and expressing the hope that a word from the Emperor would suffice to better the situation, assuring his Majesty that they were prepared to sacrifice their lives for the autocracy. (Reuter)

div.head: STROMBOLI AGAIN ACTIVE. ERUPTION AND SHOCK

div.p: The Stromboli voleano has had a strong eruption accompanied by a shock, which broke the cable between Lipari and Stromboli. (#H.)
The estimates presented to the Reichstag include 15,000,000 marka, being the first in- stalment, for enlarging the Kiel Canal and adapting it for modern battléships. (Reuter)

The "Tribuna" asserts that agreements con- cerning the Mediterranean have been concluded between England, Spain, France, and Italy, ( Havas) KING EDWARD'S TOUR. Naples, April 27, After visiting Palermo, King Edward re- turned to Naples. (Havas) Naples, April 28, King Edward will leave on Tuesday for Rome. (Reuter)
The Dowager Empress has arrived. (Havas)

Seven robbers were killed in a collision with the Turkish troops in Macedonia. (Havas)

The report of the international financial commission shows that in 1906 the receipts set apart for the debt amount to 53,637,061 drachms as compared with 49,122,847 in 1905, and notifies a constant lower rate of exchange. ( Havas)
Mohamed el Torres has asked the customs to allow material for radiography to pass (H.)
Russia and Japan have come to an agree- ment concerning the fisheries. ( Havas)

In consequence of the unrest at Lahore permission has been gived to volunteers to withdraw rifles and 20 rounds of ball ammuni- tion from the armouries, Five judges and many officials, professors, engineers, and bankers have joined the volunteers as privates, (Reuter)
The first class armoured cruiser Defence has been launched at Pembroke. Her speed will be 23 knots. (Reuter)
Amin-es-Sultan has arrived. He was received in audience by the Shah immediately.( Reuter )
Two thousand cooks have gone on strike. (Havas) SNOW IN EUROPE. PARIS, April 27. During the evening snow fell at Paris, Reims, and Metz. (Havas)

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY. ——— A. S. C.
FIRST SUMMER MEETING
div.p: Favored with better weather good sport, a more numerous and enthusiastic attendance, the second afternoon of the meeting was certainly more enjoyable than that of Thurs- day. Under such conditions it is really a pleasure to be present at the pleasant grounds of the Sporting Club, not a little adding to the charm of the afternoon being the exquisite toilettes of some of the ladies present. It is really difficult to specialise any particular race, almost all being keenly fought contests, but perhaps the National Stakes, the Grand Prize of Alexandria, and the Pony Handicap were the best. Although only three went to the post for the first the excitement of the neck and neck race between Princess and Gou- vernant resulting in a narrow victory for Princess, compensated for the small field. The Grand Prize of Alexandria brought out the largest field of the afternoon, resulting, after a [good race, in a win for the outsider Au Revoir. The last race of the day the Pony Handicap went to Frou Fron, fiields riding a brilliant race in overtaking Fadgham. During the 5th race the Ramleh Scurry, Challoner the rider of Damon was thrown, owing to Digby on Khadouf drawing out from the inside and cannoning Damon. We were pleased to learn that except for a shaking Challoner was un- hurt. The Band of the 1st Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers conducted by Bandmaster Fawcett added to the enjoyment of the after- noon by a pleasant selection of music.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL YACHT CLUB REPORT FOR 1906.
div.p: The fifth annual report of the working of the Khedivial Yacht Club was presented to a general meeting to be held on March 26th 1906 which was adjourned to April 2nd, 1906, when the accounts for 1905 were passed and the committee and officers elected for the year. The total number of members is now 215 being an increase of 6 on the previous year On referring to the statement of accounts it will be noticed that the Alexandria Municipality made a donation of LE 50, and they have moreover kindly promised to increase it this year to L.E. 75. Donations for prizes were also kindly given by the Sporting Club and A. Chitty Bey. The committee gratefully acknow-ledge the kindness of these gentlemen. On the expenditare side of the balance sheet it is clearly shown in what way the reyenue of the club has been spent ; there being a balance in hand of LE. 279: 211m/m. A great many improvements have been carried out this year, including a new staircase from the jetty up to the club house, and further improvements are contemplated. The whole of the roof of the club has been asphalted which has proved very effective, inasmuch as during the heavy rains of the past winter not a single leak has been found. The new boat-shed and slip have brought in a sum of over L.E. 45 ; some of the money lent by the committee to build this shed has been refunded, and over L.E. 91 has been spent in still improving the foreshore, although the sea this winter has again done a great deal of damage to the same which will cost a fair sum to put back again in proper order ; this may he expected for one or two years until the new filling in has properly settled down. This is the first year that the club has not had recourse to its committee for defraying various expenses such as those incurred: by entertain- ments, special "at bemes" etc., the increase in the annual subscriptions approved last yeer having enabled it to hold its own, although through the most regretted death of H.H. Prince Mohamed Ibrahim, it has not received his usual donation of £50. The buffet has cleared expensed, having made a profit of LE. 2 after all expenses are paid, including the wages of special waiters on regatta days Under the heading of new furniture ete., the repairs to furnitare have been very great, and this will always be the case so long as it is exposed to the elements. during the winter, It can only be avoided by building a store to put the chairs, etc. in, as the present store is much too small. With reference to the sailing, the number of regattas held during the year was 24, and the average number of yachts sailing in each was 16. This is the highest nomber yet reached, the maximum number on any one day having been 20 on Angust 29th. The club has gone ahead in this respect by leaps and bounds, there being over 8% sailing yachts owned by the club members on the books ; moreover there are now 2 steam yachts which fly the club's burgee: The " Cuhona " 500 tons of our commodore His Highness Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan and " El Metwakil" of His. Highness Prince Mohamed Aly Pacha. Several members have built. new yachts such as W.R. Grafton Bey's " Ram-Seas " and Mr: Schaar's " Feu-Follet;" others have ob-tained new yachts from Europe, such as Mr. J. Chini's " Ananké " and Mr, T. McClure's " Banshee I1:" the latest arnval from Southampton, and we understand that several more are expected this year. In the Club races a monthly prize was given for points scored, and a small weekly prize for the first boat in every regatta in both classes. Owing to the great number and ' variety of the Club's yachts it is proposed this year to have three |: classes as follows :—I. rating, II. large class, III. centre board and small class No I explains itself and will be entirely by measurement for yachts specially imported for racing No. II will include the old boats of the type of Masr, Shamrock, Jessica, Rosamund ete No. III}. will be for the' present small class. and in this as well as in class II the handicap will be based -on results, Prices will.be given in, all three classes. The commodore's cups were raced for on May 30th and were won by the " Delikanh " in class and the " Cattleya " in| class JI. The Sporting Club's cups - were raced for on August 29th and won by the "Nanine" and " Shamrock " respectively. A Chitty Bey's cup was raced for on Septem- ber 26th and won by the " Iskindiriyah." His Highness the Khedive again graciously honoured the club by paying it a visit on October 13th, when a special regatta was organized for the occasion, and His Highness's challenge cup was won-by Mr, Fenderl in the "Iskindiriyah". On the same day the "Club International, dei Canottieri" again carried away the annual cup given by the Yaoht Club; this is the third year in succession that this olub has won it, His Highness also very kindly gave us £50 for two more challenge cups like the present one, so that now each class will have a challenge cup to race for. The committee gratefully acknowledges the kind assistance rendered and the facilities offered by the Officials of the Porta "and Lighthouses Ad ministration and the Harbour Police, and also thank the committees and members of the Khedivial Club for kindly putting a room at the disposal of the Yacht Club whenever. required for moetings etc We are not asked to announce that the first regatta of the season will take place on May 8th.

Evans, Starter.

div.head: FRESKEL.
div.p: WHAT IT IS
FRESKEL is a dry powdered preparation for Wall and Ceiling Decoration, made ready for use with the addition of water.
It is easily prepared and applied.
WHAT IT DOES
FRESKEL, covers well, and works easy Does not crack, peel, or show brush marks. Does not rub off.
